moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 e6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 a6 5. Nc3 Qc7 6. Bd3 Nc6 7. Nxc6 bxc6 8. O-O Nf6 9. Bg5 Bd6 10. Kh1 Bf4
comment: Black fights on the dark squares and encourages the trade of Bg5 for either Black piece. In this case I'd think trading it for Bf4 should be better, because White can gain even more from weakening square d6, though he couldn't then play f2-f4 as easy as he'd like.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 e6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 a6 5. Nc3 Qc7 6. Bd3 Nc6 7. Nxc6 bxc6 8. O-O Nf6 9. Bg5 Bd6 10. Kh1 Bf4 11. Bxf4 Qxf4 12. Qe2 d5 13. Rae1 O-O 14. Na4 a5 15. b3
comment: White seems to shy away from every variation which calls for a commitment of pawn structure. Na4-b6xc8 should be a plus. Leaving Pb2 as long as possible should be better than bringing it closer to Pa5 & Pc6. Offering a queen trade by Qe2-e3 might be useful to fight on dark squares.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 e6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 a6 5. Nc3 Qc7 6. Bd3 Nc6 7. Nxc6 bxc6 8. O-O Nf6 9. Bg5 Bd6 10. Kh1 Bf4 11. Bxf4 Qxf4 12. Qe2 d5 13. Rae1 O-O 14. Na4 a5 15. b3 Rd8 16. e5
comment: At this stage of the game this doesn't seem likely to succeed. Only by really securing c5 could he hold Black down long enough to make any real gains. This is a pretty good indication Black has fully equalized.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 e6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 a6 5. Nc3 Qc7 6. Bd3 Nc6 7. Nxc6 bxc6 8. O-O Nf6 9. Bg5 Bd6 10. Kh1 Bf4 11. Bxf4 Qxf4 12. Qe2 d5 13. Rae1 O-O 14. Na4 a5 15. b3 Rd8 16. e5 Nd7 17. g3 Qb4
comment: That's confidence his king-side is impenetrable. He continue to fight for the central dark squares and c5.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 e6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 a6 5. Nc3 Qc7 6. Bd3 Nc6 7. Nxc6 bxc6 8. O-O Nf6 9. Bg5 Bd6 10. Kh1 Bf4 11. Bxf4 Qxf4 12. Qe2 d5 13. Rae1 O-O 14. Na4 a5 15. b3 Rd8 16. e5 Nd7 17. g3 Qb4 18. f4 c5
comment: threatening ...c5-c4 since Pb3 is tied to defending Na4

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 e6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 a6 5. Nc3 Qc7 6. Bd3 Nc6 7. Nxc6 bxc6 8. O-O Nf6 9. Bg5 Bd6 10. Kh1 Bf4 11. Bxf4 Qxf4 12. Qe2 d5 13. Rae1 O-O 14. Na4 a5 15. b3 Rd8 16. e5 Nd7 17. g3 Qb4 18. f4 c5 19. c3 Qb7 20. Kg1 g6
comment: It may look locked-up, but Black has pawn moves to open some lines and White has to play around the existing pawn structure: there's no time for h2-h4-h5xg6 to open the g-file.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 e6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 a6 5. Nc3 Qc7 6. Bd3 Nc6 7. Nxc6 bxc6 8. O-O Nf6 9. Bg5 Bd6 10. Kh1 Bf4 11. Bxf4 Qxf4 12. Qe2 d5 13. Rae1 O-O 14. Na4 a5 15. b3 Rd8 16. e5 Nd7 17. g3 Qb4 18. f4 c5 19. c3 Qb7 20. Kg1 g6 21. c4
comment: So, White tries to lock the queen-side more firmly.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 e6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 a6 5. Nc3 Qc7 6. Bd3 Nc6 7. Nxc6 bxc6 8. O-O Nf6 9. Bg5 Bd6 10. Kh1 Bf4 11. Bxf4 Qxf4 12. Qe2 d5 13. Rae1 O-O 14. Na4 a5 15. b3 Rd8 16. e5 Nd7 17. g3 Qb4 18. f4 c5 19. c3 Qb7 20. Kg1 g6 21. c4 Nb6
comment: Again Rublevsky shows great confidence, here gambitting a pawn to force open lines.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 e6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 a6 5. Nc3 Qc7 6. Bd3 Nc6 7. Nxc6 bxc6 8. O-O Nf6 9. Bg5 Bd6 10. Kh1 Bf4 11. Bxf4 Qxf4 12. Qe2 d5 13. Rae1 O-O 14. Na4 a5 15. b3 Rd8 16. e5 Nd7 17. g3 Qb4 18. f4 c5 19. c3 Qb7 20. Kg1 g6 21. c4 Nb6 22. Nxc5 Qc7 23. Qf2 dxc4 24. bxc4 Na4 25. Nxa4 Rxd3
comment: The logjam is broken and Pc4 is a sitting duck. Black's Bc8 will come into play in a huge way, with the a8-h1 diagonal completely weak.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 e6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 a6 5. Nc3 Qc7 6. Bd3 Nc6 7. Nxc6 bxc6 8. O-O Nf6 9. Bg5 Bd6 10. Kh1 Bf4 11. Bxf4 Qxf4 12. Qe2 d5 13. Rae1 O-O 14. Na4 a5 15. b3 Rd8 16. e5 Nd7 17. g3 Qb4 18. f4 c5 19. c3 Qb7 20. Kg1 g6 21. c4 Nb6 22. Nxc5 Qc7 23. Qf2 dxc4 24. bxc4 Na4 25. Nxa4 Rxd3 26. Nc5
comment: This is an excellent way to keep Bc8 undeveloped.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 e6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 a6 5. Nc3 Qc7 6. Bd3 Nc6 7. Nxc6 bxc6 8. O-O Nf6 9. Bg5 Bd6 10. Kh1 Bf4 11. Bxf4 Qxf4 12. Qe2 d5 13. Rae1 O-O 14. Na4 a5 15. b3 Rd8 16. e5 Nd7 17. g3 Qb4 18. f4 c5 19. c3 Qb7 20. Kg1 g6 21. c4 Nb6 22. Nxc5 Qc7 23. Qf2 dxc4 24. bxc4 Na4 25. Nxa4 Rxd3 26. Nc5 Rc3 27. Qd4 Rc2 28. Rb1 Qc6 29. Rf2 Rxf2 30. Kxf2 Ba6 31. Qd6 Qxd6 32. exd6 Bxc4
comment: Black regains the pawn, but at the cost of giving up on a direct attack on Kg1. Also, White's Nc5 & Pd6 look very menacing. White has done terrifically to keep all his pieces working. As they near the time control (move 40 one presumes) Black must be very careful.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 e6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 a6 5. Nc3 Qc7 6. Bd3 Nc6 7. Nxc6 bxc6 8. O-O Nf6 9. Bg5 Bd6 10. Kh1 Bf4 11. Bxf4 Qxf4 12. Qe2 d5 13. Rae1 O-O 14. Na4 a5 15. b3 Rd8 16. e5 Nd7 17. g3 Qb4 18. f4 c5 19. c3 Qb7 20. Kg1 g6 21. c4 Nb6 22. Nxc5 Qc7 23. Qf2 dxc4 24. bxc4 Na4 25. Nxa4 Rxd3 26. Nc5 Rc3 27. Qd4 Rc2 28. Rb1 Qc6 29. Rf2 Rxf2 30. Kxf2 Ba6 31. Qd6 Qxd6 32. exd6 Bxc4 33. d7 Rd8 34. a4 Kf8 35. Rb7 Bd5 36. Ra7 Ke7 37. Rxa5 Kd6 38. Ke3 f6 39. Kd4 e5+
comment: It seems Black's king activity should ensure equality (Pd7 falls if Nc5 ever moves and Ra5 can't beat Black by itself) .

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 e6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 a6 5. Nc3 Qc7 6. Bd3 Nc6 7. Nxc6 bxc6 8. O-O Nf6 9. Bg5 Bd6 10. Kh1 Bf4 11. Bxf4 Qxf4 12. Qe2 d5 13. Rae1 O-O 14. Na4 a5 15. b3 Rd8 16. e5 Nd7 17. g3 Qb4 18. f4 c5 19. c3 Qb7 20. Kg1 g6 21. c4 Nb6 22. Nxc5 Qc7 23. Qf2 dxc4 24. bxc4 Na4 25. Nxa4 Rxd3 26. Nc5 Rc3 27. Qd4 Rc2 28. Rb1 Qc6 29. Rf2 Rxf2 30. Kxf2 Ba6 31. Qd6 Qxd6 32. exd6 Bxc4 33. d7 Rd8 34. a4 Kf8 35. Rb7 Bd5 36. Ra7 Ke7 37. Rxa5 Kd6 38. Ke3 f6 39. Kd4 e5+ 40. fxe5+ fxe5+ 41. Kd3 Bc6 42. Kc4 Bd5+ 43. Kd3 Bc6 44. Ke3 Rf8 45. Ne4+
comment: White does a nice job of keeping the game alive. By forcing these pawn exchanges all the pieces become more free to move about.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 e6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 a6 5. Nc3 Qc7 6. Bd3 Nc6 7. Nxc6 bxc6 8. O-O Nf6 9. Bg5 Bd6 10. Kh1 Bf4 11. Bxf4 Qxf4 12. Qe2 d5 13. Rae1 O-O 14. Kxf2 Ba6 31. Qd6 Qxd6 32. exd6 Bxc4 33. d7 Rd8 34. a4 Kf8 35. Rb7 Bd5 36. Ra7 Ke7 37. Rxa5 Kd6 38. Ke3 f6 39. Kd4 e5+ 40. fxe5+ fxe5+ 41. Kd3 Bc6 42. Kc4 Bd5+ 43. Kd3 Bc6 44. Ke3 Rf8 45. Ne4+ Kxd7 46. Ra7+ Ke6 47. Rxh7 Rf1

1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 e6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 a6 5. Nc3 Qc7 6. Bd3 Nc6 7. Nxc6 bxc6 8. O-O Nf6 9. Bg5 Bd6 10. Kh1 Bf4 11. Bxf4 Qxf4 12. Qe2 d5 13. Rae1 O-O 14. Na4 a5 15. b3 Rd8 16. e5 Nd7 17. g3 Qb4 18. f4 c5 19. c3 Qb7 20. Kg1 g6 21. c4 Nb6 22. Nxc5 Qc7 23. Qf2 dxc4 24. bxc4 Na4 25. Nxa4 Rxd3 26. Nc5 Rc3 27. Qd4 Rc2 28. Rb1 Qc6 29. Rf2 Rxf2 30. Kxf2 Ba6 31. Qd6 Qxd6 32. exd6 Bxc4 33. d7 Rd8 34. a4 Kf8 35. Rb7 Bd5 36. Ra7 Ke7 37. Rxa5 Kd6 38. Ke3 f6 39. Kd4 e5+ 40. fxe5+ fxe5+ 41. Kd3 Bc6 42. Kc4 Bd5+ 43. Kd3 Bc6 44. Ke3 Rf8 45. Ne4+ Kxd7 46. Ra7+ Ke6 47. Rxh7 Rf1 48. Nc5+ Kd6 49. Nd3 Rf3+
comment: Suddenly Black's pieces work together nicely and Rh7 seems hopelessly out of place.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 e6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 a6 5. Nc3 Qc7 6. Bd3 Nc6 7. Nxc6 bxc6 8. O-O Nf6 9. Bg5 Bd6 10. Kh1 Bf4 11. Bxf4 Qxf4 12. Qe2 d5 13. Rae1 O-O 14. Na4 a5 15. b3 Rd8 16. e5 Nd7 17. g3 Qb4 18. f4 c5 19. c3 Qb7 20. Kg1 g6 21. c4 Nb6 22. Nxc5 Qc7 23. Qf2 dxc4 24. bxc4 Na4 25. Nxa4 Rxd3 26. Nc5 Rc3 27. Qd4 Rc2 28. Rb1 Qc6 29. Rf2 Rxf2 30. Kxf2 Ba6 31. Qd6 Qxd6 32. exd6 Bxc4 33. d7 Rd8 34. a4 Kf8 35. Rb7 Bd5 36. Ra7 Ke7 37. Rxa5 Kd6 38. Ke3 f6 39. Kd4 e5+ 40. fxe5+ fxe5+ 41. Kd3 Bc6 42. Kc4 Bd5+ 43. Kd3 Bc6 44. Ke3 Rf8 45. Ne4+ Kxd7 46. Ra7+ Ke6 47. Rxh7 Rf1 48. Nc5+ Kd6 49. Nd3 Rf3+ 50. Ke2 e4 51. Nf2 Ke5 52. Re7+ Kd4 53. Re6 Bd5 54. Rxg6 Bc4+ 55. Ke1 e3 56. Rg4+ Kd5 57. Rxc4 exf2+ 58. Kf1 Kxc4
comment: When Black's pieces worked together properly White's looked pathetic. From the end position Black only needs to play Kc4-e3 and then move his rook around to White's back rank, to force the advance and promotion of Pf2. White's pawns are far too slow to stop this.
